title: How to Clean Oil Stains with Baking Soda: Clothes, Concrete & More

steps.title: Cover a fresh oil stain with baking soda and let it sit overnight.
steps.content: Cover a fresh oil stain with baking soda and let it sit overnight. First, says Stocker, use a cloth or paper towel to blot up as much of the extra oil as you can. Then generously sprinkle baking soda onto the stain. Let it sit overnight so the baking soda can absorb the oil, then brush away the powder the next morning. [1] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Professional Cleaner Expert Interview. 8 November 2019. After that, spritz the fabric with a 1:1 mixture of water and vinegar and let it sit for about 30 minutes, then gently scrub the spot with dish soap and a toothbrush until it's gone. [2] X Research source You don't have to pile up the baking soda, but do make sure that it covers the stain completely so you can't see the fabric beneath. Avoid rinsing the oil spot before trying to clean it. The water will form a coating around the oil and make it harder to remove. Once the stain is gone, blot away the soap with a damp cloth, or toss the item into the washing machine if it's washable. steps.title: Attack stubborn oil stains with baking soda and a laundry pre-treater.
steps.content: Attack stubborn oil stains with baking soda and a laundry pre-treater. Squirt a laundry stain pre-treater (like Shout) onto a set-in oil stain (i.e., an oil stain that's been sitting for a few hours), then sprinkle 1 tsp of baking soda on top of it. Rub the baking soda into the pre-treater with a toothbrush until it makes a paste, and then sprinkle on another layer of baking soda. Let the mixture sit overnight (or for at least 12 hours) before washing it on a normal cycle. [3] X Research source If the stain is still there after you finish washing the garment, repeat the whole process until it's gone.

steps.title: Clean dried oil stains with dish soap and an enzyme-based detergent.
steps.content: Clean dried oil stains with dish soap and an enzyme-based detergent. Baking soda works by absorbing and breaking down the oil before it fully sets into fabric fibers. Once the oil stain is dried, especially if you put it in the dryer, baking soda won't work as well – but liquid dish soap and an enzyme-based laundry detergent may be able to remedy the problem! Enzyme-based detergents break down tough oil and grease stains. [4] X Research source To clean dried oil stains off your clothes, squeeze a few drops of dish soap onto the stain, let it absorb for a few seconds, then rub it in with your fingers or a soft bristle brush (like a toothbrush). Leave the dish soap to sit for another 5 minutes, then toss it in the washer with enzyme-based laundry detergent and wash it on the hottest temperature your clothes can withstand.

steps.title: Absorb fresh oil spills on your driveway with a thick layer of baking soda.
steps.content: Absorb fresh oil spills on your driveway with a thick layer of baking soda. You might have heard of people using kitty litter or sawdust to absorb motor oil from their driveway. Well, baking soda works the same way! Stocker says to "pop on baking soda" right after a spill, so you can "soak it up as soon as possible." [5] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Professional Cleaner Expert Interview. 28 February 2023. After the oil is absorbed, rinse it off with water. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub away old oil stains from your driveway with baking soda paste.
steps.content: Scrub away old oil stains from your driveway with baking soda paste. Wet the stain thoroughly with water, then mix baking soda and water together in a cup or bowl until they form a paste. Spread the paste on the stain and scrub it with a stiff-bristle brush, then rinse the whole area clean with fresh water. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Sprinkle the stain with baking soda and let it sit overnight.
steps.content: Sprinkle the stain with baking soda and let it sit overnight. If the stain is fresh, blot up as much excess oil as possible with a paper towel before you start treating the area. Then, after leaving a generous layer of baking soda on the stain overnight (or for at least 12 hours), vacuum the carpet thoroughly. [8] X Research source If the oil stain is still visible after following the steps above, try blotting it with a couple of drops of dish soap and a damp towel or sponge. Then rinse the area by pressing a warm, damp towel against it. Dry it with another towel, sprinkle more baking soda, and let it sit overnight again. The next day, vacuum the baking soda up like you did before. There is a chance the baking soda might clog your vacuum filter, and it could even find its way into the motor, damaging the machine . [9] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe up the oil spill with paper towels and sprinkle baking soda on the stain.
steps.content: Wipe up the oil spill with paper towels and sprinkle baking soda on the stain. The baking soda will break up the remaining oil and make cleaning it up easier. Let it sit for at least 10 minutes, then vacuum it or wipe it up with paper towels. Remove any remaining oily residue by gently rubbing the area with liquid dish soap and water and a damp cloth or sponge. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Can you mix baking soda and laundry detergent?
steps.content: Can you mix baking soda and laundry detergent? Yes, you can use baking soda and laundry detergent in the same wash! Baking soda can make your clothes look brighter and smell fresher. Just add about ½ c (4 oz) to your washing machine, then add in the clothes and laundry detergent and wash as usual. [11] X Research source However, if you're trying to remove oil from your clothes, it's most effective to treat the stain with plain baking soda first before the wash.

steps.title: Can baking soda ruin fabrics?
steps.content: Can baking soda ruin fabrics? It won't damage the color, but its pH is harsh on delicate fabrics. Baking soda is generally pretty safe to use on most fabrics, and Stocker says it's a great addition to your laundry if you want to brighten your clothes and remove odors. [12] X Expert Source Susan Stocker House Cleaning Professional Expert Interview. 8 November 2019. However, baking soda has a high pH, meaning it's alkaline, so it can damage natural fibers like wool or silk. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Will baking soda damage my carpet?
steps.content: Will baking soda damage my carpet? Not most carpets, but it could damage the floor underneath. Be sure not to pile up the baking soda on your carpet—a thin layer is plenty. If you use too much, it could accumulate on the floor underneath, and since it's slightly abrasive, it could damage that flooring. [14] X Research source
